nodes.text: Monetary transactions among many agents can be analyzed with statistical physics methods: conservation-like accounting of money plus stochastic transaction rules yield characteristic probability distributions and mechanistic insights into inequality, money creation, debt dynamics, banking, and policy effects
Money obeys a local conservation law in agent-to-agent transactions: when agent A pays delta to agent B, the sum of their money balances is unchanged

Applying Boltzmann kinetic equation and, for small transfers, the Fokker-Planck equation to conserved monetary exchanges yields an exponential stationary distribution P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm) under time-reversal symmetry or additive transaction assumptions

Time-reversal symmetry of microscopic transaction rules is sufficient for the Boltzmann-Gibbs exponential money distribution; absence of that symmetry (e.g. multiplicative percentage transfers) produces nonexponential (Gamma-like or power-law tail) distributions

Entropy maximization (Boltzmann principle) under fixed total money explains evolution from equal initial balances to unequal exponential distribution and implies spontaneous increase of inequality in a closed monetary ensemble with boundary conditions

Agent-based simulations with nonnegative-money boundary (m>0) show initial equality is unstable and stationary distribution becomes exponential; removing the lower boundary (allowing unconstrained debt) prevents equilibration

Distinction between monetary layer (digital conserved tokens) and physical layer (goods, nonconserved) is essential: wealth combines layers via prices but behaves differently from money in transactions and over time

Wealth (money plus priced physical holdings) can change between transactions via price changes or production, so kinetic conservative transfer models should refer to money, not wealth, to avoid conceptual confusion

Debt is a distinct promissory layer: borrowing creates matched positive money and negative debt obligations (particle-antiparticle analogy) so net worth may remain unchanged but removes the lower-bound constraint and permits runaway negative balances

If debt is unrestricted, the net worth distribution broadens without reaching equilibrium (entropy grows without bound); interest increases divergence; only explicit debt constraints or legal enforcement can stabilize system-level debt

Commercial banks do not create net exogenous money but create matching deposits and loan obligations (debt); reserve-requirement multiplier limitations are weak or circumventable in practice, so banks effectively create debt at large scale

Large-scale endogenous debt expansion via banking, followed by correlated defaults, forces central banks to monetize losses by creating exogenous money to stabilize the system, producing the lend-crash-bailout cycle

Empirical analysis of US income data shows a two-class structure: a majority lower class with exponential income distribution parameterized by temperature T and an upper class with a power-law tail; shocks and policy actions (bubbles, quantitative easing) increase the upper-class share and measured inequality
Quantitative Easing and central-bank bailouts channel newly created exogenous money toward financial institutions and upper-class asset holders, thereby increasing income and wealth inequality

Because large-scale capitalist profits and interest flows ultimately rely on state-provided exogenous money during crises and monetization of debt, the state is the ultimate source of aggregated capitalist monetary profit

Limitations and assumptions: analysis assumes identifiable conserved monetary accounting boundary, validity of statistical equilibrium concepts for monetary layer, and simplified transaction rules; macroeconomic globalization and institutional details can alter local outcomes
